overview.definition: Invasive procedure to isolate pulmonary veins and eliminate AF triggers/substrate

success_rates.paroxysmal_af: 80-90% freedom from AF at 1 year (single procedure)
success_rates.persistent_af: 60-80% freedom from AF at 1 year (single procedure)

overview.durability: Long-term success maintained in 70-80% at 5 years

class_i: Symptomatic paroxysmal AF refractory to or intolerant of ≥1 AAD
Symptomatic persistent AF refractory to or intolerant of ≥1 AAD
class_iia: First-line therapy for symptomatic paroxysmal AF (patient preference)
Symptomatic AF patients with heart failure
emerging_indications: Young patients to avoid lifelong AADs

imaging: Transthoracic echocardiogram (LA size, LV function, valves)
TEE to exclude thrombus (especially if suboptimal anticoagulation)
Cardiac CT or MRI for LA anatomy and PV assessment
Consider coronary angiography if CAD risk factors

ablation_strategy.standard: Pulmonary vein isolation (PVI) - cornerstone of all procedures

radiofrequency.technique: Point-by-point ablation with contact force sensing

cryoablation.limitations: Less precise, cannot perform linear lesions

procedural_endpoints: Entrance block: No conduction into PVs
Exit block: No conduction out of PVs

types.prevention: Therapeutic anticoagulation, ICE guidance, air embolism prevention
types.management: Immediate neurology consultation, IV thrombolytics if appropriate

types.prevention: Avoid ablation within PVs, anatomic mapping
Esophageal temperature monitoring, reduced power on posterior wall
types.presentation: Fever, sepsis, neurologic symptoms 1-4 weeks post-procedure

types: Radiation skin injury (rare with modern techniques)

immediate: 4-6 hours bed rest with leg immobilization
Vital signs and vascular checks q15min x 4, then q30min x 4
Chest X-ray to rule out pneumothorax
anticoagulation: Continue anticoagulation ≥2 months (regardless of CHADSVASC score)
Long-term anticoagulation based on CHADSVASC score
medications: Continue pre-procedure AADs for 3 months (blanking period)

blanking_period.definition: First 3 months post-ablation when AF recurrence doesn't count as failure
blanking_period.rationale: Inflammation and healing may cause transient arrhythmias
management: Don't discontinue anticoagulation solely based on AF absence

timeline.assessment: Wound check, symptoms, basic metabolic panel

timeline.actions: Discontinue AAD if no recurrence, reassess anticoagulation

timeline.assessment: Symptoms, ECG, event monitor or 7-day Holter
timeline.actions: Consider repeat procedure if symptomatic recurrence

success_definition.primary_endpoint: Freedom from AF/AT/AFL >30 seconds after 3-month blanking period

indications: Documentation of AF on extended monitoring
strategy: Linear lesions or posterior wall isolation

heart_failure.considerations: Higher complication risk, may need staged approach
heart_failure.outcomes: Significant improvement in EF and symptoms

elderly.age_considerations: >75 years associated with lower success, higher complications
elderly.alternative: Rate control may be preferred in very elderly

persistent_af.challenges: Lower success rates, more extensive substrate
persistent_af.duration_effect: Success inversely related to AF duration

surgical_ablation.indications: Concomitant cardiac surgery, failed catheter ablation

left_atrial_appendage_occlusion.indications: High stroke risk, contraindication to anticoagulation
left_atrial_appendage_occlusion.note: Not a treatment for AF rhythm, only stroke prevention

cost_effectiveness.long_term_savings: Reduced hospitalizations, medication costs, improved QOL

realistic_expectations: May need 2-3 procedures for optimal results
Some patients may still need medications
lifestyle_modifications: Weight loss if overweight (>10% weight loss reduces AF)
warning_signs: Chest pain or severe shortness of breath

overview.definition: Restoration of normal sinus rhythm using electrical or pharmacologic methods

indications: Symptomatic AF refractory to rate control

anticoagulation_strategy.duration_less_48h: Can proceed without anticoagulation if low stroke risk
anticoagulation_strategy.duration_more_48h: 3-4 weeks therapeutic anticoagulation before, 4 weeks after
anticoagulation_strategy.tee_guided: TEE to exclude thrombus → immediate cardioversion → 4 weeks anticoagulation

procedure.synchronization: ALWAYS synchronized to avoid VF induction

amiodarone.advantages: Safe in structural heart disease, hemodynamically stable

ibutilide.dosing: 1mg IV over 10min, may repeat once after 10min

propafenone.contraindications: Structural heart disease, CAD, heart failure
